> Even more unfortunate, in my view, is that JMX can only interoperate

th Java solutions.

The OpenMBean specification is meant to ameliorate this=
 shortcoming,  
and Heritrix uses Open MBeans exclusively. There is to my k=
nowledge  
no universal OpenMBean connector that would allow non-Java progr=
ams  
to easily

Happily, this should change shortly. We are working with s=
everal  
international partners to create a web services interface to Herit=
rix  
in the first few months of 2008.

If you or anybody else on the list =
has specific ideas/features they'd  
like to see in such an interface, plea=
se reply to this thread.

> I=92m pretty much agreed on this. I think that =
JMX will never be
> sufficient for complete or near-complete solution for c=
omplete remote
> control of heritrix (

We're shooting for near-complete.

=
> including delete of all information related to a
> job,

The current Engi=
ne deleteJob method only deletes the job's  
subdirectory; if you're storin=
g logs or BDBs on other disks they  
aren't affected. It doesn't seem like =
it would be hard to add a new  
JMX method to "fully delete" a job. Such a =
method would just scan the  
settings for a job and delete every file setti=
ng mentioned; would you  
mind opening a Feature Enhancement in JIRA for th=
is?

> management of completed jobs,

Please say more about this. Other tha=
n full removal of a completed  
job, what other management features would y=
ou like to see?

> retrieval of logs & arcs, etc.);

This is the only one I=
 disagree with. Again, I wouldn't want to  
implement a whole entire file s=
ystem inside of Heritrix. Though I  
suppose simple read-only streaming for=
 large files may be desirable  
enough to warrant the extra effort, especia=
lly if we're embedding an  
HTTP service anyway.

-Paul
